instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.820-00164: What is 820-00164? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.P3V3S5_EN_R: What is P3V3S5_EN_R? P3V3S5_EN_R is an enable signal that turns on the PP3V3_S5 power rail.  Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. The _R means the signal is asserted when the voltage is high(3.3v). .

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG_R</SIGNAL> - 0.54v
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board not liquide damaged.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG_R</SIGNAL> - 0.54V

In diode mode - 0.400 and 0.366

I replaced <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>, <CAPACITOR>C7592</CAPACITOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR>

Still 0.54V

I injected 3.5V there and no consum at all - 0V

Thanks for help.

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG_R</SIGNAL> - 0.54v
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_R</SIGNAL> high?

If yes maybe make sure <RESISTOR>R7516</RESISTOR>/46/60/61/63 are within specification. But 90% of the time its just a bad IC
Does anything look bad in the area?

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG_R</SIGNAL> - 0.54v
threads.message: I would start by checking PPBUS.....

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG_R</SIGNAL> - 0.54v
threads.message:
PPBUS - 8.59V
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_R</SIGNAL>  - 3.3V
EN - 3.3V
VREG3 - 0V  (no short there)
VREG5 - 0.32V (no short there)

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG_R</SIGNAL> - 0.54v
threads.message: Replace the chip again, you probably just had bad luck

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG_R</SIGNAL> - 0.54v
threads.message: Blindly replacing chips? I say VIN trace to pin 23 on <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> corroded.
